definitions.definition: to make something longer or larger

examples.text: to extend a fence/road/house
There are plans to extend the children's play area.
The Democratic candidate **extended her** early **lead** in the polls.
There are plans to extend the road network in the north of the country.
You can add value to your house by extending or renovating it.

definitions.sensetop: extend somethingextend something for somethingextend something to somethingextend something from somethingextend something from something to something

examples.text: to **extend a deadline/visa**
Careful maintenance can **extend the life** of your car.
The show has been extended for another six weeks.
The proposal was to extend paid leave to six months.
Contracts were gradually extended from the initial single year.
The repayment period will be extended from 20 years to 25 years.
examples.contextForm: extend something from something to something

definitions.definition: to make a business, an idea, an influence, etc. cover more areas or operate in more places
definitions.sensetop: extend somethingextend something to somethingextend something into something

examples.text: The school is **extending the range** of subjects taught.
a terrorist organization intent on **extending its reach**
The service will soon be extended to other areas of the UK.
The company plans to extend its operations into Europe.

definitions.definition: to relate to or include somebody/something

examples.text: The offer does not extend to employees' partners.
His willingness to help did not extend beyond making a few phone calls.

definitions.definition: to cover a particular area, distance or length of time

examples.text: Our land extends as far as the river.
His writing career extended over a period of 40 years.
The wood does not extend very far.
The country's power extends far beyond its military capabilities.

definitions.definition: to make something reach something or stretch

examples.text: to extend a rope between two posts

definitions.definition: to stretch part of your body, especially an arm or a leg, away from yourself

examples.text: He **extended his hand to** *(= offered to shake hands with)* the new employee.
to **extend the hand of friendship** to *(= try to have good relations with)* another country

definitions.definition: to offer or give something to somebody
definitions.sensetop: extend something to somebodyextend somebody something

examples.text: I'm sure you will join me in extending a very warm welcome to our visitors.
to **extend your sympathy/congratulations/thanks** to somebody
to extend hospitality to overseas students
The bank refused to extend credit to them *(= to lend them money)*.
to **extend** somebody **an invitation**
They extended the invitation to all members of staff.
We extend our greetings to you and thank you for listening to us.
We extend our sympathy to the families of the victims.
Benefits must be extended to all workers.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something use all their effort, abilities, supplies, etc.

examples.text: Jim didn't really have to extend himself in the exam.
Hospitals were already fully extended because of the epidemic.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin extendere ‘stretch out’, from ex- ‘out’ + tendere ‘stretch’.
